data.title: The Week in Oil: U.S.-Iran Tensions Keep Risk Premium High
data.description:
By Giulia Petroni

Here's a look at what happened in oil markets in the week of Feb. 23-27 and what the focus will be in the days to come.

OVERVIEW: Oil prices jumped on Friday, driven by concerns over potential U.S. action against Iran after talks in Geneva ended without a breakthrough. Crude benchmarks are at their highest level in about seven months, with Brent crude above $72 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate at $66 a barrel.

MACRO: Markets are still betting that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates further this year, though the pace of potential cuts remains uncertain.

The latest U.S. producer price index data showed that wholesale inflation unexpectedly accelerated in January. The PPI is closely watched because several of its components feed into the calculation of the personal consumption expenditures price index, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge.

At the same time, uncertainty surrounding U.S. tariff policy and the future of existing trade agreements following a recent Supreme Court ruling continues to weigh on market sentiment.

GEOPOLITICAL RISKS: The U.S. and Iran are set to resume discussions next week after the latest round of talks concluded on Thursday without reaching an agreement. Further negotiations "at a technical level" will take place in Vienna, Oman's Foreign Minister Badr bin Hamad al-Busaidi said in a post on X.

Markets remain cautious, however, as any escalation in tensions could threaten energy flows, particularly after Washington increased its military presence in the Middle East. The impact of potential U.S. military action on oil prices would largely depend on whether it disrupts global supply and shipping traffic through the Strait of Hormuz.

SUPPLY AND DEMAND: The broader outlook remains bearish, as global oil supply is still expected to exceed demand this year. Under normal circumstances, such a surplus would put significant downward pressure on prices. Instead, crude futures have held up, supported by persistent geopolitical tensions that continue to sustain a sizeable risk premium in the market.

At the same time, U.S. crude inventories surged by 16 million barrels last week to 435.8 million barrels--far above expectations and marking the largest weekly increase since February 2023, the EIA said.

NEXT WEEK: Heightened uncertainty over developments in the Middle East is expected to keep a significant risk premium embedded in oil prices, as markets weigh the possibility of supply disruption.

"President Trump's deadline for an agreement expires in a week at the latest," analysts at Commerzbank said. "The continuing risk of a U.S. military strike is therefore likely to remain the dominant issue on the oil market, which suggests that oil prices will remain well supported."

Traders are also focused on the upcoming OPEC+ meeting on Sunday for guidance on future production policy, with the group now widely expected to resume output increases, beginning with a modest 137,000 barrel-a-day rise.

On the economic front, investors will be watching some remarks from Federal Reserve speakers, manufacturing PMI, ADP employment figures and weekly jobless claims for fresh clues on the strength of the economy and interest-rate outlook.

Write to Giulia Petroni at giulia.petroni@wsj.com

data.title: Pemex Cuts 4Q Loss As Operating Results Improve
data.description:
By Anthony Harrup

MEXICO CITY--Mexican state-owned oil company Petróleos Mexicanos slashed the size of its net loss in the fourth-quarter as operating results improved despite lower revenue.

Pemex reported a loss of 147 million pesos ($8.5 million) for the October-December quarter, compared with a loss of MXN350.5 billion in the year-earlier period.

Lower cost of sales, lower fixed-asset impairment and lower taxes and duties, along with a foreign exchange gain, contributed to the improved net result, Pemex said Friday.

Sales fell 16% to 362.4 billion, affected by lower crude oil volume and prices, which was partially offset by higher volume and prices for domestic sales of gasoline, diesel, fuel oil and jet fuel. Operating profit was MXN20.3 billion, compared with an operating loss of MXN41.5 billion in the fourth quarter of 2024.

Crude oil and condensates production averaged 1.65 million barrels a day, down 1.3% from a year earlier, affected by the decline of mature fields, increased drilling complexity, adverse weather and delays in infrastructure installation, Pemex said. Natural gas production rose 7.4% to 3.879 billion cubic feet a day.

Pemex's refineries processed 1.14 million barrels a day of crude oil in the quarter, a 44% increase from a year earlier. Production of petroleum products rose 42% to 1.18 million barrels a day. Gasoline production increased to 433,000 barrels a day from 295,000 barrels a day, and diesel output rose to 293,000 barrels a day from 172,000 barrels a day.

Pemex's financial debt ended the year at $85.2 billion, down from $100.3 billion at the end of September following substantial financial support from the federal government.

Write to Anthony Harrup at anthony.harrup@wsj.com

data.title: Figs Climbs on 4Q Earnings Beat, Growth Outlook Despite Tariffs
data.description:
By Elias Schisgall

Shares of Figs climbed after the company blew past Wall Street estimates in the fourth quarter and said it expects revenue growth in the current year, even despite President Trump's new push for 15% global tariffs.

Shares were up 17% to $14.53 midday Friday. The stock has gained more than one-and-a-half times its value in the past year.

The healthcare apparel company on Thursday recorded a profit of $18.5 million, or 10 cents a share, compared with a profit of $1.9 million, or one cent a share, a year earlier.

Revenue jumped to $201.9 million, up from $151.8 million a year prior.

Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting earnings of two cents a share and $165.3 million in revenue.

For the current year, the company is expecting revenue to grow between 10% and 12%. It expects growth in the low-20% range during the first quarter.

"At the same time, we expect increased profitability, even with the latest announcement calling for 15% global tariffs," Chief Financial Officer Sarah Oughtred said.

Write to Elias Schisgall at elias.schisgall@wsj.com

data.title: Blue Owl turmoil adds to strain in $2 trillion US private credit sector
data.description:
Key points:
  • Blue Owl's turmoil weakens private credit sector confidence
  • AI advances threaten software companies in private credit portfolios
  • Private credit market faces increased competition and valuation concerns

By Saeed Azhar, Saqib Iqbal Ahmed and Matt Tracy

The $2 trillion private credit industry, which has expanded over the past decade from financing leveraged buyouts to areas banks dominated, is facing fresh strain from turmoil at Blue Owl Capital, a major private lender.

Sentiment was already hit by questions about valuation and transparency, and specific situations such as the bankruptcy of auto-parts supplier First Brands, which some private credit players had exposure to.

Concerns have been compounded by troubles at Blue Owl , which emerged late last year when it moved to limit withdrawals from a fund. In recent days, the firm has worried investors by selling shares of other alternative asset managers.

The collapse of UK mortgage provider Market Financial Solutions is adding to wider concerns about lending standards and the fast-growing market for private finance.

Some say the industry's size is working against it. State Street estimates the addressable market for private credit has grown to more than $40 trillion, including investment-grade credit.

"Private credit's golden era is not over yet, but the days of generating equity-like returns might be," said Kyle Walters, U.S. private equity analyst at PitchBook. "Moreover, private credit has reached a certain scale in recent years, leading to more players entering the asset class and increasing competition."

BLUE OWL PAIN

Blue Owl's turmoil matters well beyond the firm itself because of its scale, role in private credit markets, and close ties with institutional investors, corporate borrowers and wealthy individuals.

Blue Owl, which managed more than $300 billion in assets as of December 31, said last week it would sell $1.4 billion of assets across three funds, return part of the proceeds to some investors and pay down debt. It permanently removed an option for investors in the smallest vehicle, mainly wealthy individuals, to withdraw some funds every quarter.

Credit rating firm Moody's said Blue Owl's latest decision to pivot away from traditional quarterly redemptions has sharpened investor focus on how semi‑liquid private credit vehicles manage redemptions, especially with growing retail participation.

Blue Owl declined to comment.

"Retail investors tend to be less patient and predictable than institutional investors," said Johannes Moller, vice president for Moody's Ratings, in a report on Tuesday.

Moller said rising redemption pressure is showing up across the private credit market — including at perpetual non‑traded loan vehicles, or BDCs, which offer retail and high-net-worth investors access to private credit — amid concerns about valuations and liquidity terms.

As alternative managers push further into the retail channel, Moody's expects liquidity management, disclosure, and fund structure design to become more central to investor decision‑making — and potentially a drag on returns.

Blue Owl shares are down 29% year to date, while other major alternative asset managers are also lower. Shares of Blackstone are down nearly 27%, Apollo Global Management is down over 26% and Ares Management is down almost 31% this year.

Blackstone and Ares declined to comment, but pointed to recent comments by senior executives. Apollo did not respond to a request for comment.

"We enter 2026 in a position of strength," said Ares CEO Michael Arougheti on the company's earnings call, citing strong underlying performance across the portfolio, and improving capital markets and M&A backdrop.

Blackstone CFO Michael Chae said at a financial conference this month credit quality remains strong, but cautioned about an increase in defaults for the industry from an extremely low level.

"The structural advantages will continue to produce superior results. So, overall, outstanding momentum to our credit business as we move into 2026," he said.

SOFTWARE EXPOSURE STRESS

Shares of other private equity firms and alternative asset managers are also facing mounting unease over valuations of software companies that they own and lend to, as artificial intelligence threatens to upend business models.

"It’s not clear that things have fundamentally changed, but there’s an idea that there's a technology risk that may not have been fully priced in or contemplated as recently as three, six, or 12 months ago," said Christian Hoffmann, head of fixed income at Thornburg Investment Management.

INDUSTRY GROWTH

The private credit industry has evolved from providing direct loans to middle-market companies to asset-backed finance — loans backed by collateral such as hard assets.

Banks have also announced their private credit foray with JPMorgan Chase setting aside $50 billion for its direct lending push last year, while others have partnered with alternative asset managers on private credit strategies.

A recent Moody's report showed U.S. banks had lent nearly $300 billion to private credit providers as of June 2025. Banks loaned a further $285 billion to private equity funds and had $340 billion in unutilized bank lending commitments available to these borrowers.

Moody's has projected the industry's size to double to $4 trillion by 2030, but cautioned deepening ties between private credit funds and traditional financial institutions could heighten contagion risk in a downturn.

JPMorgan said this week it was watching the private credit market closely.

"I'm shocked that people are shocked. The reality is in this environment, as the world gets more volatile, as you get towards the end of the cycle, this outcome should be expected," Troy Rohrbaugh, co-CEO of JPMorgan Chase's commercial and investment bank, told investors on Monday, referring to private credit concerns.

data.title: Credit Market Likely to Offer Good Returns this Year — Interview
data.description:
By Miriam Mukuru

Credit markets are likely to perform well this year, supported by solid economic growth in major economies and interest-rate cuts by the U.S. Federal Reserve, Alain Krief, head of fixed income at Edmond de Rothschild Asset Management, said.

The U.S., China and Europe, which form the biggest part of the global economy, are expected to record resilient growth, boosting credit returns, Krief said.

In addition, further interest-rate cuts from the Fed should create a good environment for global economic growth, he said.

U.S. money markets price in two 25 basis-point interest-rate cuts by the Fed this year, and a small chance of a third rate cut, LSEG data show.

Edmond de Rothschild Asset Management is particularly positive about banking sector bonds and emerging-market credit.

The broad credit market is in good shape, Krief said. Credit spreads are near their tightest levels and aren't expected to widen considerably.

However, tight spreads mean investors need to identify sectors that could deliver superior returns, he said.

Some sectors, such as the software industry, are under pressure because of artificial-intelligence-related risks, and this has created opportunities to invest in specific industries and names that have good value.

Banking sector bonds look particularly attractive, Krief said.

"Banks have quite solid fundamentals and they are very well capitalized."

Subordinated bank bonds are especially appealing due to their elevated yields. These bonds are high-risk investments, vulnerable to credit risk and extension risk, but these threats seem very low currently, he said.

Emerging-market corporate bonds are also favorable for investors who have a higher risk tolerance, Krief said.

These bonds are expected to benefit as U.S. rate cuts prompt investors to seek higher yields elsewhere, he said.

Edmond de Rothschild Asset Management has 107 billion euros ($126 billion) in assets under management, the company said.

Write to Miriam Mukuru at miriam.mukuru@wsj.com

data.title: France's Dekuple posts rise in 2025 net sales
data.description:
Overview

  • France-based communication and data marketing firm's 2025 net sales rose 11.4% yr/yr

  • Company's digital marketing net revenue grew 17.2%, driving overall revenue growth

  • International net revenue surged 153.9%, marking major expansion milestone

Outlook

  • Dekuple plans to scale up digital and international activities for profitable growth

  • Company aims to industrialize marketing performance through data, technology, AI

Result Drivers

  • DIGITAL MARKETING GROWTH - Digital marketing net revenue rose 17.2%, driven by expansion and improved second-half momentum

  • INTERNATIONAL EXPANSION - International net revenue surged 153.9%, bolstered by acquisitions in Germany, Netherlands, and Spain

  • AI AND TECHNOLOGY - AI and agent-based systems integrated across activities, enhancing service delivery

data.title: S&P 500, Nasdaq on track for biggest monthly drop in a year as AI worries bite
data.description:
Key points:
  • Indexes down: Dow 1.22%, S&P 500 0.66%, Nasdaq 0.99%
  • Block surges on plan to cut 4,000 jobs on AI bet
  • Netflix climbs after ending Warner Bros Discovery pursuit

By Ragini Mathur and Shashwat Chauhan

Wall Street's main indexes dropped on Friday as AI anxiety hammered technology stocks, with the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 on pace for their steepest monthly loss since March 2025, while hotter-than-expected inflation data also weakened sentiment.

Technology shares faced selling pressure this month as concerns over high valuations and the uncertain payoff from Big Tech's massive AI spending grew.

Nvidia slid 2.4% after plunging more than 5% in the previous session despite strong earnings, a sign that risk sentiment for all things AI remained shaky.

The broader technology index tumbled 1.7%, while financials dropped 2.1%, with both poised for sharp monthly declines.

Big banks including Goldman Sachs and private credit firms such as KKR & Co were among the biggest laggards.

Jefferies dropped 9.5% after media reports that the investment bank and other lenders face potential losses related to the collapse of UK mortgage provider Market Financial Solutions Ltd.

Risk appetite also took a hit after data showed U.S. producer prices increased more than expected in January, suggesting inflation could pick up in the coming months.

"Inflation has reared its ugly head, and the questioning of the true value of technology firms has resulted in a major selloff," said Ben Fulton, CEO of WEBs Investments.

While losses in cyclical sectors dominated on Friday, investors appeared to rotate towards more defensive sectors, with consumer staples , utilities and healthcare rising more than 1% each.

At 11:47 a.m. ET, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 602.06 points, or 1.22%, to 48,897.14, the S&P 500 lost 45.92 points, or 0.66%, to 6,862.94, and the Nasdaq Composite was down 226.61 points, or 0.99%, to 22,651.77.

Earlier in the day, brokerage UBS said it had cut its recommended allocation to U.S. equities to "neutral", citing the relatively lower sensitivity of U.S. corporate earnings to global growth as well as high valuations among other reasons.

Tariff uncertainty also fueled volatility this month after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down most of Trump's 2025 duties, prompting a temporary 10% global tariff that began on Tuesday.

Zscaler plunged 15% after the cloud security firm reported a wider net loss in the second quarter. The broader software index (.SPLRCIS) lost 1.9%.

Software shares and several industries were rocked earlier this year too, on fears of industry wide AI-driven disruptions.

Netflix added 10% as investors cheered its decision to exit the fight for Warner Bros Discovery , which dropped 2.1%. Paramount Skydance rose 18% after winning the race for some of the world's most prized TV and film assets.

Jack Dorsey's Block surged 13.1% after the payments firm said it would cut more than 4,000 jobs, nearly half its workforce, as part of an overhaul to embed AI across operations.

Dell climbed 20.5% after the PC-maker said it expects revenue from its key AI-optimized servers business to double in fiscal year 2027 and promised to return more cash to shareholders.

Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a 1.58-to-1 ratio on the NYSE and by a 2.17-to-1 ratio on the Nasdaq.

The S&P 500 posted 37 new 52-week highs and two new lows, while the Nasdaq Composite recorded 50 new highs and 86 new lows.

data.title: DUSK (DUSK) - Aegis Protocol Upgrade - 03 March 2026
data.description:
The Aegis Protocol Upgrade is a mandatory network upgrade for all DUSK node operators, activating on 3 March 2026 at 11:00 AM UTC. According to the Dusk Foundation’s announcement, the release is described as the project’s most significant upgrade so far, focused on strengthening the network and hardening security while laying technical groundwork for future features. For traders, successful execution reduces protocol and security risk, which can support a higher valuation multiple if market confidence increases. However, any implementation issues, node fragmentation, or unforeseen bugs around activation could temporarily disrupt network reliability and weigh on DUSK price.

Dusk
@DuskFoundation

Aegis Protocol Upgrade is coming.

Our most significant upgrade to date that strengthens our network, hardens security and lays the foundation for what's next.

Activation: 3rd March at 11AM UTC

This is a mandatory upgrade for all node operators. pic.twitter.com/IBlfaPrVDS

Feb 27, 2026

data.title: THORWallet (TITN) - TITN Community Unlock - 03 March 2026
data.description:
The TITN Community Unlock on 3 March 2026 at 15:00 CET (14:00 UTC) lets users deploy previously unlocked TITN to increase their share of a 5,000,000 TITN airdrop. As outlined in THORWallet’s post, merged unlocks allow holders to consolidate and use unlocked tokens to boost rewards, with top wallets targeting 200,000+ TITN. Mechanically, this creates a short-term incentive to accumulate or retain TITN to maximize airdrop allocation, which can generate buy pressure and higher on-chain activity into the event. After distribution, increased circulating supply and concentrated large rewards may introduce sell pressure, so traders should watch vesting behavior and on-chain flows closely.

data.title: Illuvium (ILV) - Beyond New Wave - 12 March 2026
data.description:
Illuvium is launching a new wave of its Illuvium Beyond content on 12 March 2026. In the project’s teaser, the team confirms that a fresh “Illuvium Beyond” wave will drop on that date, signaling another cycle of collectible or ecosystem-related releases. For ILV, new content waves can drive user engagement, secondary-market activity, and speculative interest around the broader Illuvium ecosystem, which may translate into higher demand for ILV exposure if participants expect increased platform traction. However, the direct on-chain economic impact depends on how much this wave actually uses ILV or contributes to protocol revenue, so price reaction may be driven more by sentiment than fundamentals.

Kieran.eth

data.title: Applied Optoelectronics Shares Surge On Narrower 4Q Loss, 1Q Revenue Outlook Beat
data.description:
By Amira McKee

Shares of Applied Optoelectronics soared after the semiconductor company narrowed its fourth-quarter loss on better-than-expected revenue, and projected first-quarter revenue that beat analyst estimates.

The stock was up 42% to $76.29 in midday Friday trading, after touching a new 52-week high of $79.50 earlier in the session. The shares have more than tripled in the past year and are on pace for the largest percent gain since November 2024.

The maker of optical networking products recorded a fourth-quarter net loss of $2 million, or three cents a share, compared with a loss of $119.7 million, or $2.60 a share, a year earlier.

Adjusted loss came in at one cent a share, outperforming the loss of 11 cents a share that Wall Street had anticipated, according to FactSet.

Revenue jumped 34% to $134.3 million, topping the $132.3 million that analysts polled by FactSet expected.

Applied Optoelectronics anticipates logging a first-quarter adjusted net loss of $7 million to $300,000, on revenue in the range of $150 million to $165 million. Wall Street forecast an adjusted loss of $3.8 million and revenue of $153 million, according to FactSet.

Write to Amira McKee at amira.mckee@wsj.com

data.description:
RNS Number : 7928U Maven Income and Growth VCT 3 PLC 27 February 2026  

Maven Income and Growth VCT 3 PLC - Share Buy-back and Total Voting Rights

On 27 February 2026, Maven Income and Growth VCT 3 PLC (the Company) purchased, for cancellation, 1,004,959 of its own Ordinary Shares at 44.40p per share.

As a result, and in accordance with the Financial Conduct Authority's Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules, the Company confirms that its issued share capital as at close of business on 27 February 2026 comprises 147,437,350 Ordinary Shares of 10p each, with each share carrying one voting right.

The above figure may be used by Shareholders as the denominator for the calculations by which they will determine if they are required, under the Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules, to notify their interest, or a change to their interest, in the Company.

On behalf of the Board

Maven Capital Partners UK LLP

Secretary

data.title: How Tech Firms Are Enforcing AI Use — WSJ
data.description:
By Conor Grant

This is an edition of The Future of Everything newsletter, a look at how innovation and technology are transforming the way we live, work and play. If you're not subscribed, sign up here .

AI use is no longer optional if you work in tech.

While many sectors are still experimenting with artificial intelligence, the tech industry has moved to the next phase: tracking their workers' use of AI tools — and enforcing it if they have to.

This week, Katherine Bindley and Katherine Blunt report on tech companies that are factoring AI use into performance reviews and trying to track productivity gains.

From small startups to giants including Amazon, Alphabet's Google and Meta, tech companies are measuring it and in certain cases factoring it into performance reviews. For some jobs, candidates aren't even considered unless they can demonstrate AI fluency.

The approximate share of tech-industry workers who said their direct manager expects AI use in day-to-day work as of last October, up from 32% just eight months before, according to a survey from AI consulting firm Section

Even in an industry that tends to drive workplace trends, AI adoption hasn't been easy. Tech workers have many of the same feelings about AI as the broader population, including skepticism about how much time it's actually saving them. There's also the added anxiety of hearing their own CEOs talking about how AI will ultimately lead to smaller workforces.

More on this topic:

  • What AI executives tell their own kids about the jobs of the future. (Read)
  • The do's and don'ts of using AI to write performance reviews. (Read)
  • WSJ's Callum Borchers shares ways to stay sane in the AI skills race. (Read)

🤔 What are your thoughts on AI enforcement in the workplace? Send me your thoughts, questions and predictions at future@wsj.com (if you're reading this in your inbox, you can just hit reply).

More of What's Next: Apple's American Chip Push; Keeping Tabs on Grandma; a 'Fitbit for Farts'

Apple is pushing to build an all-American chip. Under pressure to diversify its supply chain away from Taiwan, the company is investing in domestic suppliers. To find out how far Apple still has to go, Rolfe Winkler went on an exclusive visit to several suppliers.

Personal Tech columnist Nicole Nguyen says Apple should copy Samsung's new security screen ASAP. She tested a new smartphone feature called Privacy Display, which obscures mobile screens from people nearby — and says this new tech could keep us safer.

You can monitor mom and dad without becoming Big Brother. Devices ranging from in-home sensors to location trackers can help families keep tabs on their aging loved ones while also respecting their privacy, writes Julie Jargon.

It's called the "Fitbit for farts," and it's no joke, writes Christopher Mims. Researchers have developed a tiny, battery-powered hydrogen sensor that continuously monitors a wearer's flatulence, with the aim of collecting data to improve digestive health.

Future Feedback

Last week, we reported on companies that are using converted jet engines to power data centers. Readers shared their thoughts on how these conversions will affect the power generation business:

  • "Airport noise next to landowners -- on top of the hum of the data centers and emergency diesel backup?! We have several data centers being built within five miles from our 'rural' houses -- some literally a few hundred feet away. We're not happy as is. The proposed pace of construction is not considering the real 'human' impact to neighbors. County commissioners are only looking at dollar signs, and not human impacts." -- Mark Slivka, Georgia
  • "This may be a godsend energy stopgap. Ultimately, more nuclear power is the long-term solution -- but it is a long-term solution." -- T.G. Nelson, Wisconsin
  • "This is a perfect example of how our capitalist economy operates. When supply and demand are out of balance, increasing prices and lack of supply bring new manufacturers and technologies into the market. 'The invisible hand' is alive and well." -- Joseph Messino, New York
  • "If you think residential neighbors are upset about having data centers built nearby in the latest version of Nimbyism, just wait to see the huge 'stink' (pun intended) they'll make about jet engine exhaust engulfing their neighborhoods!" -- Joseph Subits, Georgia

(Responses have been condensed and edited.)

Elsewhere in the Future

  • Women are falling in love with AI, and it's a problem for Beijing. (The New York Times)
  • America was winning the race to find Martian life. Then China jumped in. (MIT Technology Review)
  • Employers to job seekers: Your AI résumé isn't fooling anyone. (The Washington Post)

About Us

Thanks for reading The Future of Everything. We cover the innovation and tech transforming the way we live, work and play. This newsletter was written by Conor Grant. Get in touch with us at future@wsj.com. Got a tip for us? Here's how to submit.

See more from The Future of Everything at wsj.com/future-of-everything.
